Today is not â€œHappyâ€ Memorial Day. This day is to honor those who have died while in military service. Some people unknowingly confuse today with Veteranâ€™s Day in November, which celebrates the service of all U.S. military veterans. 
I think about and am grateful to my brothers and sisters in arms who gave it ALL during service to our great nation. In particular, today Iâ€™m thinking about the C-130 crash earlier this month in Georgia where the Air Force lost nine crew members at once, all from Puerto Rico. You will not be forgotten. ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡µğŸ‡· #USAF #PRANG #MemorialDay

OK, so itâ€™s been a while since Iâ€™ve been in FREEZING weather.  As Iâ€™m driving LJ to the bus stop this morning, itâ€™s 27 (fu*#^n) degrees outside (in Florida!!), I turn on the wipers and spray a little water like I usually do to clear a smudge on the windshield (as Iâ€™m driving). Instantly,  a thin layer of ice forms on my windshield so I canâ€™t see! Wipers are going fast, ice on windshield and the car is moving! So, I do what any other rational person would do...I roll down my window and stick my head out until I get to the bus stop!! Yeah, I looked just like youâ€™re imagining right now. 
My immediate thought was â€˜I hope I donâ€™t hit anyone walking in the streetsâ€™ and LJ is going to be REALLY embarrassed pulling up at the bus stop w/ his Dad looking like this. But nope, I look over and he has tears in his eyes from laughing so hard at me. 
Well, there you have it. After that incident, no caffeine needed this morning...Iâ€™ve already had my dose of freezing weather and adrenaline to wake me up, thank you very much! Hope youâ€™re having a better day. Stay warm. #FloridaProblems #WaterBecomesIceBelow32Degrees

Les presento la carÃ¡tula de mi nuevo sencillo, â€œPuerto Rico Se Levanta.â€ Como prometido, les contarÃ© un poco sobre la foto y porquÃ© luce en la portadaâ€¦

Con el pase del huracÃ¡n MarÃ­a en Puerto Rico vÃ­ por los medios sociales muchas fotos de la devastaciÃ³n que MarÃ­a dejÃ³ en su arrastre a la Isla. Â¡Que azotÃ³n! Como muchos desde â€˜afueraâ€™ me encontraba en un estado de shock mirando fotos de la devastaciÃ³n incansablemente hasta que frente a mi llegaron un par de fotos que me impactaronâ€¦fuerte. Eran fotos de lugares que yo bien conocÃ­a en mi pueblo donde los daÃ±os cambiarÃ­an el paisaje para siempreâ€¦nunca serÃ¡ igual. Ã‰sta foto en la portada de mi nuevo sencillo fuÃ© una de ellas. 
La foto fuÃ© tomada alto en las montaÃ±as de Utuado, mi pueblo, a solo dÃ­as despuÃ©s del huracÃ¡n. Utuado fuÃ© una de las Ã¡reas mÃ¡s afectadas. Al mirar esta foto notÃ© algo muy especial y diferente a las demÃ¡s. Las fotos que presentaban devastaciÃ³n tambiÃ©n traÃ­an angustia, dolor, y falta de esperanza. Precisamente, eso fuÃ© lo que me impactÃ³ de esta foto, el FlamboyÃ¡n aÃºn de piÃ©, sin hojas, humillado, y achantado, pero todavÃ­a en su puesto como buen soldado vigilando sobre su puebloâ€¦con esperanza de volverse a levantar. AsÃ­ veo mi Puerto Rico. Asi veo mi gente. Aunque nos dieron fuerte, nos vamos a levantar. 
La imagen no fuÃ© captada por un periodista ni con cÃ¡mara professional. FuÃ© captada por mi tÃ­a (Wilma RodrÃ­guez de Orama) con su telÃ©fono mÃ³vil frente a su casa en su batey. AprovechÃ³ un momento donde logrÃ³ conectarse con su mÃ³vil para dejarme saber que estaba bien, y me la enviÃ³ porque ella sabe lo que significa para mi. El dÃ­a que me llegÃ³ la foto ya estaba en el estudio grabando â€œPuerto Rico Se Levanta.â€ Al enseÃ±arle la foto a mis compaÃ±eros ya todos lo sabÃ­amos, esa era la foto que representaba nuestra canciÃ³n y tenÃ­a que ir en la portada. 
Ese FlamboyÃ¡n que ven en la foto es el mismo donde mis hijos llegaron admirar, subir y retratarse. Hasta llegaron bajar por la jalda que vigila en yagua. ImagÃ­nense el orgullo que sentÃ­ al ver que el FlamboyÃ¡n, aunque completamente desalojado, todavÃ­a estaba de piÃ©. Imaginar que algÃºn dia muy pronto volverÃ¡ a florecer. VolverÃ¡ como buen soldado con unif

*** ENGLISH ***
This is the CD cover for my new single, "Puerto Rico Se Levanta" (Puerto Rico will rise again). As promised, I will tell you a little about the photo and why I chose it as the cover... With the passing of Hurricane MarÃ­a over Puerto Rico came many photos across social media of the devastation that Maria left in her path on the island. Like many on the 'outside' I was in a state of shock looking at photos of total devastation, but it was not until I saw a small series of photos that I was deeply affected. These were pictures of places I knew well in my town where damages would change the landscape forever ... it will never be the same. This photo on the cover of my new single was one of them.

This photo was taken high in the mountains of Utuado, our hometown, just days after the hurricane. Utuado was one of the most affected areas. Looking at this photo I noticed something very special and different from the others. The photos I had seen of devastation also brought anguish, pain, and hopelessness. It was precisely that (hope), which struck me as different in this photo, the FlamboyÃ¡n still standing, leafless, humiliated, and practically left for dead, but still at attention in position just as a good soldier would watching over his town ... with hope of rising again. This is how I see my Puerto Rico. That's how I see my people. Although we were knocked down, we're going to get up.

This image was not captured by a journalist or professional camera. It was captured by my aunt (Wilma RodrÃ­guez de Orama) with her cell phone in front of her house in her front yard. She took advantage of a moment where she managed to connect with her cell phone to let me know she was okay, then she sent me the photo because she knows what it means to me. The day that the photo came in I was already in the studio recording "Puerto Rico Se Levanta." As I showed the photo to my colleagues we all knew, that was the photo that represented our song and HAD to go on the cover.

That FlamboyÃ¡n you see in the photo is the same one my children came to admire, climb, and take â€˜selfiesâ€™ in. They even slid down that hill it overlooks on homemade slides (yagua). Imagine the pride

Iâ€™ve never written anything so passionate. What happened in Puerto Rico last month affected me deeply. I felt helpless from the outside looking in and wanted to help the best way I could, so I put pen to paper, my thoughts flowed, and gave it a shot...with Music. 
This is a song acknowledging we were hit hard, but Boricuas are strong, and united, Puerto Rico will rise again. Working on release date. I will reveal CD Cover (Artwork) for my new single Friday, Oct 27, 2017 at 12:00 p.m. (noon - Miami time) and will tell you the story behind it. #StayTuned #PuertoRicoSeLevanta

Day #9. Toughest part so far has been dealing with my left eye being open all the time. Have to manually "blink" eye. #BellsPalsy #DryEye  #WateryEye. #AnnoyingEye
Â¡FELIZ VIERNES! ğŸŒ´ğŸŒ´ğŸ‰ğŸ¤ğŸ¶ğŸ¶ğŸŒ´ğŸ˜œğŸ˜œ

Woke up w/ my face half-paralyzed last Friday. Went to see the Doc & long story short, I've been diagnosed w/ Bell's Palsy. 
It's a TEMPORARY condition caused by any number of things and recovery time is anywhere between 2 wks-6 mos, very few suffer permanent damage. Mine was most likely brought on by upper respiratory infection...I let a cold go untreated too long :-( Most people recovered well; I hope the same for me. Since half of my face is temporarily paralyzed it's been a "fun" experience. Thought I would share with you the good and the bad.
1. THE BAD: Can't drink out of a straw (can't control half my lips so I just make a mess)
*ON THE PLUS SIDE: Now I don't look like a sissy drinking out of a straw
2. THE BAD: Left eye doesn't close so I have to wear an eye-patch to protect my eye (cornea) from debris and wind irritation. I have to either tape down my eyelid or manually blink it to avoid tearing up
*ON THE PLUS SIDE: I get to wear an eye-patch and look like a real Pirate, Arrrgh!
3. THE BAD: Food tastes "funny" (taste buds are shot)
*ON THE PLUS SIDE: Great time to expand my diet since my taste buds are on break
4. THE BAD: Can only chew on one side because only half of my mouth opens
*ON THE PLUS SIDE: Saves me time when flossing...I can floss in half the time! As a bonus, I get to lose weight by eating less!
5. THE BAD: One ear sounds too low, while the other is too loud
*ON THE PLUS SIDE: Now have a built-in monitor and it sounds better than most monitors I use on stage (musician joke, LOL)
6. THE BAD: Only half of my face smiles (lips, eyebrows, cheeks), only one eyebrow goes up
*ON THE PLUS SIDE: Wrinkles on half of my face are less visible (relaxed skin), I can raise one eyebrow like The Rock, and if this condition sticks around through Halloween, I have the perfect Two-Face costume...all I have to do is draw a line right down the middle of my face!
In all seriousness "message received" to take care of myself, cut down the stress, and focus on what's really important. I'll have to TEMPORARILY cut live performances but will maintain online. Thx to my fam for taking care of me. #bellspalsy

TONIGHT I"ll be making a SPECIAL APPEARANCE w/ Orq Urbana LIVE performing my new hit single "NOS ENTENDEMOS."

On a personal note...
I don't strive to be better singer/musician than everyone else, I strive to be the best musician I can be. That's it! I completely get that my best may not be as good as other's best...I'm ok with that. It is what it is. I can honestly tell you that I truly enjoy surrounding myself w/ musicians/singers that are better than me. It's so exciting for me to be in their company when beautiful music is created. In the end I can only worry about what I can control, and that's ME. Thank you all for allowing me to share my musical experiences w/ you. I will continue as long as God allows me to, and as long as I continue to receive support. :-) #QueVivaLaSalsa #IvanMontero
